text:
Hello,
I am looking for guidance when using Flumine. I want to manually force/enter an order using the API. What would you recommend?
I see a few options:
Option1: I create a separate program that uses BetfairLightWeight only. No Flumine involved.
Option2: I create a strategy in Flumine that triggers an order when receiving a CustomEvent.
Option3:  I run flumine and share the BetfairClient as shown below:
```trading = betfairlaightweight.APIClient("username")
client = clients.BetfairClient(trading)
framework1 = Flumine(client=client)
framework2 = GatewayToSendOrder(client=client)```
Others?
Thank you for your help!

elements.text:
Hello,
I am looking for guidance when using Flumine. I want to manually force/enter an order using the API. What would you recommend?
I see a few options:
Option1: I create a separate program that uses BetfairLightWeight only. No Flumine involved.
Option2: I create a strategy in Flumine that triggers an order when receiving a CustomEvent.
Option3:  I run flumine and share the BetfairClient as shown below:

trading = betfairlaightweight.APIClient("username")
client = clients.BetfairClient(trading)
framework1 = Flumine(client=client)
framework2 = GatewayToSendOrder(client=client)

Others?
Thank you for your help!

text: <@U01A5GVTBST> why not one process? order placement is a couple of includes and you rid yourself of lots of possible things to break / easier to do integration testing

elements.text: why not one process? order placement is a couple of includes and you rid yourself of lots of possible things to break / easier to do integration testing

text: Would that take place within Flumine? The idea is to prepare an order (in CSV or via API like Oliver & liam suggested) but, then, where does the reading of the CSV is taking place? In a Strategy? A background worker?

elements.text: Would that take place within Flumine? The idea is to prepare an order (in CSV or via API like Oliver & liam suggested) but, then, where does the reading of the CSV is taking place? In a Strategy? A background worker?

text: My suggestion would be that your prediction / recommendation engine project should have a few more modules that interact with flumine. So you still launch a flumine strategy when it comes time to trade, first that process instantiates your prediction engine and then it instantiates relevant flumine pieces. please take a look the example strats. Unless the recommendation engine is super heavy, splitting up recommendations from the trading is not a good idea because you’ll add a ton of code complexity (csv, redis, zmq etc) and backtesting will be that much harder

elements.text: My suggestion would be that your prediction / recommendation engine project should have a few more modules that interact with flumine. So you still launch a flumine strategy when it comes time to trade, first that process instantiates your prediction engine and then it instantiates relevant flumine pieces. please take a look the example strats. Unless the recommendation engine is super heavy, splitting up recommendations from the trading is not a good idea because you’ll add a ton of code complexity (csv, redis, zmq etc) and backtesting will be that much harder

text: prediction and trading should be one process for the vast majority of cases

elements.text: prediction and trading should be one process for the vast majority of cases

text:
```def process_market_book(self, market, market_book):
    recs = self.recommendation_engine.produce_recommendations()
    for r in recs:
        order = self.turn_rec_to_order_price_size(r)
        self.place_order(order)```
trivial code example

elements.text: trivial code example

text: as long as that prediction doesnt take too long, otherwise you will backlog market books

elements.text: as long as that prediction doesnt take too long, otherwise you will backlog market books

text: yes absolutely, conflate_ms may be the first thing to try then. once you are totally comfortable that single process is giving you the behaviour, then look into background worker or zmq to trigger orders

elements.text: yes absolutely, conflate_ms may be the first thing to try then. once you are totally comfortable that single process is giving you the behaviour, then look into background worker or zmq to trigger orders

text: <@U01JKBAUFQA> has joined the channel

When using market recorder in flumine, what is the best way to keep the zipped files? I only just realised flumine is deleting them after 3600 seconds, so all my recorded markets are gone.

Should I setup a crontab to move zipped the files out before flumine deletes them? Or is there a background worker that does this?

Should I setup a crontab to move zipped the files out before flumine deletes them? Or is there a background worker that does this?

text: Just update the MarkettRecorder strategy so it does what you want, it’s just an example (delete code is in clean_up)
